text:
( caption revisions in progress )
>> This episode of the Modern Rogue
brought to you by NordVPN.
>> Go to nordvpn.com/rogue
and get 75% off a three-year plan,

that's less than $3 a month.
>> Yeah, and if you spell it

right, R-O-G-U-E, we'll even
give you an extra month free.
♪ You're welcome ♪

>> Don't make us send
the knight after you,
because he will show you no mercy.

>> Also he'll just stand
there, he's creepy.
It's haunted, it's a haunted knight.
Hey Trever, just answer the question.
>> Answer the question, Trever.
>> Does the glass matter, does it matter?

>> Yes!
>> Huh, good episode.

>> Cool, okay, good.
>> That was fast.
[record static playing]

>> All right, we're
back at Parker Jazz Club

with our favorite bartender
Trever Fehrenbach.

>> So let's talk about the
different shapes of things.

I do believe, as we
learned with our experience

with The Beerists, that
the shape of the glass
does everything from affect the aromatics,
as we hung out with the Whiskey Tribe,
we learned that the Glencairn is their

preferred whiskey-drinking
vessel of choice.
Can you give us just a broad overview
of why the shape of the vessel matters?

>> It's not only the shape,
for instance, the tiki mug.

Why does it look like this?
>> I don't know, it's haunted.

They're haunted drinks,
>> Definitely could.

>> I've seen him drink
them and it ends badly.

>> It's like with
drinking, cursed glassware.

>> [snickers] Well essentially
what you have there is

take brown, dark liquor
and any other color,

what are ya going to get?
>> Oh!
Something that looks like poop!
>> So why not put it in something--

>> So you hide the diarrhea
behind an opaque ceramic mug.

That's amazing, now that
I'm thinking this through,

it occurs to me that
different vessels carry
temperatures at different speed,

and all of that must matter.
>> It's actually called
thermal lag, and with the tiki mug,

with it being ceramic,
it's actually going to keep
the ice colder longer than glass or metal.
>> So this has an insulating effect.

This is a drink that
is not very attractive

to look at, but it matters
that the ice sticks

around the entire drink
long, essentially you have
basically a YETI cooler or something.
>> And it's another way for a bar to make,

you know, a quick $20 when
they're wanting to leave.

>> That matters too.
>> Know where that came from?

>> [stammering] Target?
>> Ah, well, that is

the iconography of the
people of the South Pacific,
brought back by GIs from World War II.
>> And there was an adverse effect to that
because of the GIs who were stationed
in Japan after the war and wanted to drink

a cocktail, Japan
learned how to make them,

and make them better
and actually influenced

the cocktail boom of
2006, all the way back

right after World War II.
>> True fact,

those shipping lanes,
now called the GI tract.
[all burst out laughing]

[Trever claps]
>> Well done.
>> All right, what's next? [chuckling]
Talk to me about the martini.
>> Are you sure it's a martini glass?
Are you sure it's not a cocktail glass?

>> Oh, [stammering] I don't
know, [Jason drowns him out].
>> I mean it looks like a martini glass.
>> Look, all I know is I go to an airport,
and I want a Jameson, and there's this
on the picture, so I go there.
>> The original cocktail glass was

a slimmer, smaller version
of the martini glass.
In 1925, the Parisians then introduced

a wider base to the
drink, and then decided
to call it the martini glass for any drink

that was up, the stem
on the end, obviously,
was there to keep your hand away from it
from keeping the drink getting warm.

>> Oh of course, because
if you're doing this,

it's going to get way
too warm way too fast.

>> And you can't put ice
in a glass that small.

>> From a design standpoint,
this suddenly makes

so much sense.
>> So what kind
of cocktails would you put in there?

>> TREVER: It's going to
be anything that's up,
say a Manhattan, a martini, something
that has been stirred, that has already
chilled and is going to stay chilled
because you are no longer holding onto it.
>> And if I were to speculate wildly,
I would guess that this implies

that there's not much
of an aromatic nature
to experience when you drink a martini.
It's not like you sit there and sniff

the martini beforehand.
>> You're actually,

you're right on track there,
and it's not the GI tract,

what it is, it's actually
the wider surface is

for you to gulp it quicker.
>> Got it!
So you sell more, you move them fast,

>> Ah.
>> they look fancy.

>> A little-known fact,
if you get a martini,
however many olives are in it,
that's how many drinks it should be.
So if you have a three-olive martini,

it should be three gulps.
>> How did I not know this?

>> I've never heard that.
>> This is amazing!

>> But talk to the Spaniards,
talk to the Italians,

you're going to get
different amounts of olives

because they're superstitious
about odds and evens.

>> [snorts] Okay,
fascinating, what's next?

>> That's the highball.
>> No no no, this is

a cosmopolitan, isn't it?
>> No.
>> [mumbles] Long Island Iced Tea.
This is [stammering] this is a spyglass.
We're suddenly an improv troupe.

>> Help us here!
>> I heard dentist. [laughs]

>> This is a Collins glass.
>> What?

>> Aw, like for a Vodka
Collins or a Tom Collins?
>> Now, some people may believe
that it's named after Tom Collins,
but it's actually John Collins
who is mentioned in a poem from a bar
in London in the late 1700s about being

the head server at this
bar, and he invented a drink

that eventually became
known as the Tom Collins.
>> Whenever someone would order it,
he would have to go, "It's John."
>> "I'm right here, right here."
>> "It's John, not Tom, it's John."
>> That's right, "Tom is my dad."
>> It has always been the Collins glass,
whether or not we know whether it was

Tom or John or whoever,
but when Jerry Thomas's

book came out, who is
the father of mixology,

he called it the Tom
Collins because the drink
originally called for Old Tom gin.
>> So somebody conflated the two,
and that's how we ended up with this.
All right, so if I was going to guess,

based on what you told us
about the martini glass,
I'm going to guess that again, it's not
that you want to slam it down really fast,

but you also really don't
care about the aromatics
in there, also it's fine if the ice melts,
that's why your hand is all over this.

It does seem like an
efficient design as well,

whereas this seems fairly
inefficient for space,
this is just like, drink goes here,
fist goes here, belly gets full.

>> That's a good point
on the martini glass,

because when you're
holding a martini glass
in a social arena, say, you are trying

to make points, you're
talking, but you're slowly

gesturing, it's a slow,
methodic gathering.

Whereas a Collins, you
can run around with it.

>> Oh a Collins is an
end-of-the-evening drink.
>> Yeah, with this Collins glass,
the reason it's designed this way is
because of the Ramos Gin Fizz, which is
one of New Orleans' oldest drinks.

With the egg foam, the
drink would be here,
but the foam would come all the way up,

so that's the reason for
the tall cylinder shape,
is to catch all that egg foam.

>> This is also the
perfect shape for one of my

all-time favorite bar
bets, which is to ask,

"Which is more, the
circumference around the top,

"or the length all the
way down to the bottom?"

Most people visually just assume
it's got to be the height,
and there's no trickery here, it's just
that our brains can't conceive of the fact

that it's actually farther
around the circumference

than the height.
>> All right, what's next?
>> This is actually a Nick and Nora Glass,

and--
>> What, no!
>> Do you know who Nick and Nora is?
>> Yeah, from The Thin Man movies.
From like the '20s or '30s, those are some
of my favorite crime noir thrillers.
>> What is happening?

>> It was a couple in
the Silver Screen Era

>> Yeah.
>> that loved to drink.
>> And it was this crime-fighting couple

named Nick and Nora.
>> So what's special
about this, this seems to me to be just
a martini glass that is slightly easier
to hold in your knuckles, I guess.
>> When you asked me if the glass matters,

this time it doesn't.
[all laughing]
A Nick and Nora is a glass that's used

for a drink that you
kind of want to get down

a little bit quicker because
you might want to get out,

you got more drinking
to do somewhere else.
>> Got it, so this is just a--

>> Or you might have a crime
to solve, I don't know.
>> You don't want to say, "Gimme a shot"

so instead you say, "Give me
a Nick and Nora of blank."
>> Holy [slots bell trills], he's like

the Rain Man of glassware.
[laughing hysterically]
>> I am a legitimate bartender.

>> Here we go.
[Brian drowns Trever out]
>> That's a fancy way of drinking a shot,

so is asking for a
martini with no vermouth,
shaken, and in a martini glass,
you just want a shot of vodka.

>> Okay, I know what this
one is, this is a coupe!
>> That's the booby one, the French say,
"you don't want a booby bigger than that."
>> Marie Antoinette's breast, allegedly?
Who knows if that's true or not,

but what kind of drinks
do you put in here?

Like champagne?
>> Milk.

>> Milk, oh God.
[Brian wheezing laughter]

What's up with the coupe?
>> I don't know,
it's the opposite of a martini glass.
To me, the use of this is about not being
able to spill anything out of it,
you can swish it around, roll it around.

>> There is an irrational
amount of anxiety

I have whenever I do a
martini, I'm just like,

[groans] better drink
it as fast as possible.

Which I guess is also
what they want to do,
whereas this is meant to be held,
and you feel safe holding onto it,
and gesturing for a long time.

>> Also, try toasting
that as compared to this

when it's full.
[glasses chime]

>> Oh, yeah, absolutely.
>> Because this was
the original champagne glass,
so it was easier to toast with.

>> And whatever liquid
goes forward is going to

roll back in, whereas
this is just going to

go everywhere, so you're
safer just drinking.

>> Snifters, what do
you use a snifter for,

brandy, right?
>> Yeah, brandy, cognac.

The reason that it is
designed like this is
because it traps the gas that is emitted

from the alcohol to have,
like you talked about,
the aroma that's coming out of it, okay.

The bell at the end then
traps it at the bottom,
and when you're holding it like this,

it allows for it to be
heated up by your hand,
which you want when it comes to a cognac
or a brandy or even some whiskeys.
The reason I really love a snifter is
the presentation of a drink for a guest.
If someone wants their cognac heated up,
here's all you have to do, is
you'll take a highball glass,

fill it with hot water,
[relaxed lounge music]
you'll then take your brandy or your

snifter glass,
[liquid pouring]

[glass clinks]
>> Oh, that's clever.

>> Ah and it just warms
up the brandy for them,
and it's a nice way to present it.
Then you can just spin the glass this way
and then warm up their spirit for them.

Much like a wine glass--
>> Yeah, it'll swirl around

without spilling everywhere.
>> And you can get that aroma.

>> It's not bad.
>> So now that we've, oh.

Here we go, now we've also
got the highball there,
which I thought was called a tumbler?
>> Tumbler, highball, rocks glass,
they all have different variations.

Highballs used to be a
little bit bigger as well.

Highballs are your one-and-ones,
your gin and tonics,
your gin and sodas, your vodka sodas,

your whiskey and ginger,
your whiskey and sodas,

whiskey and coke.
>> You called those one-and-one

so just one ingredient and
another ingredient, okay.

>> Yeah, a spirit, mixer.
>> Okay.
>> And that's what a highball's all about,

there's really nothing fancy
about 'em, does it matter?
Mm, depends on how much mixer you want,

so yes, the size would then
come into play on that one.

>> It does make a lot of
sense, everything else

seems to have a reason
for it, give or take,
but this one just is like, it's a cup.
>> Taste-wise, no, for the flavor, no,
but for a bar, yes, because they're short,
you can stack 'em, you need more of them
because more people are drinking them,
and if they break, they're cheap.

>> And finally, what is
this called, the mule cup?
>> Mule cup, back to the thermal lag,
that's actually escaping so fast

that it's not keeping
it as cold as a ceramic.

>> So this is a case
where you actively want
the ice to be melting as fast as possible,
so you're able to hold it in your hands

and suddenly just eh what,
you're watering it down?
>> They have a deep bell to them,
you're putting a lot of ice in it,
you're drinking this drink quick.
If someone's drinking a mule,
they'll have two or three, this has more

of a sleek design to it,
and I'm starting to see

a lot more mules coming
out slenderer, taller,
and sheen with no buck kick to it.

>> I don't know, sorry,
what is a buck kick?

>> The original mule cup
had dents all over it,

it was a failed business,
and when these two men

who were trying to sell
their vodka got together

with this woman who was
trying to sell her copper cup,
because it had all these dents in it,
it was right before The Cold War.

In order to just kind
of throw a little shade

at the Russians, we put a
vodka in an American cup
that had been kicked by a donkey.

>> Ah.
>> Got it.

>> Throwing a little shade.
>> If you must have

that Soviet beverage,
why don't you have it

in something that's been
kicked around by a donkey.

>> I've seen lately the
trend is to call them

American mules, back
then there was nothing

more American than a donkey
kicking a Russian spirit.

>> All right, so you've
got a surprise for us,

your favorite glassware
to cap it all, go ahead.
[relaxed lounge music]

>> The shot glass.
>> Okay, I...
Mm, mm, mm, okay, uh sure, why not.

>> TREVER: Do you want
to know why it matters?

>> Why?
>> Quick delivery.
>> Yes, you're right, because actually,
even if it's the same volume of liquid
at the bottom of a tiki glass,

with all this texture
and ridges and all that,
you're going to be [giggling] doing this

[talking over each other]
trying to get your shot.

>> Oh bring that up again.
>> Minimize the surface area
on there, actually you know what,
I think you brought me on board.

>> All right, Trever,
where can we find more

of your magic online?
>> Barstooltheory,
Instagram, Twitter, that's my handle.
>> Easily bribed in Rumple Minze.
Delivered in his favorite vehicle.

Where's the Rumple Minze?
>> Oh, no.

>> They don't carry it
in this bar for a reason.

>> This has the words Rumple
Minze, I always thought

that was a bit, he
really loves, all right.

>> Do you wear any armor when
you're surfing the internet?
>> I mean, I should, fire comes at you
when you're on the internet.

>> Or?
>> Onions?
>> Bathtub full of poop!

The armor protects you.
[Brian wheezes]

>> Okay, explain to me
this whole metaphor.
In this story, what is NordVPN?
>> NordVPN is the armor, that is the armor

that you wear when you're
surfing the internet

with Nord, it protects people
from getting in your biz!

And all the slings and
arrows of outrageous websites

and bad actors and
people tracking your biz.

That protects you, man!
>> Sounds to me
like what you're trying to say is

that NordVPN is our favorite

something that makes you more anonymous,

more protected, so you're
not constantly seeing

all these targeted ads or
maybe you're geo-blocked

>> Yes, Nord keeps you

>> And on top of all of

>> Nonstop.
>> Best part,
super, super cheap, you would think

less than $3 a month

>> Yeah, man, what are you doing?
Put on some clothes for crying out loud.

at 75% off, that's less

>> Also you'll be keeping us in business,

go to battle naked, where

is that a thing?
>> The Celts, actually,
would show their bits under their kilts,

which seems really reckless
to me, I prefer that.

I prefer Nord, don't get
hit by internet poop.

>> Thank you NordVPN, I
hope they let us run this.
[both laughing]
Brian Brushwood, legitimate historian.

>> Oh God that was good.
[Brian laughing]

I thought he actually had,

>> I thought he remembered something
from a documentary all of a sudden.

>> Like, I said it, and then--

I was like, GI tract, oh.
